member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvSystem.DetectionTimeout
member.summary: Time to search the system for devices.

remarks.para: Time the #PvSystem::Find methods wait for responses from GigE Vision or Pleora Protocol devices before returning.
GigE Vision devices may wait up to 1 second before answering a discovery request and this detection timeout allows enough time for all discovery answers to come back in.
USB3 Vision devices detection is instant. You can set this timeout to its minimum supported value if you are only interested in detecting USB3 Vision devices.

Pleora Protocol and some GigE Vision devices answer as soon as the discovery request is received. Experimenting with this timeout and discovery stability is a way improving discovery performance. Another would be to stick with the safe, default delay and use the event sink callback to be notified as soon as a device is discovered.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvSystem.FindDevice(System.String)
member.summary: Finds devices until a specific device is found.
member.remarks:
Performs a standard find operation and keeps listening for answers until a specific device is found.
More than one device can be found and added to the interfaces during this find operation. Do not assume only the device of interest is present in the system/interface data after this method returns.
If the device of interest is found, a handle to the device info in the interface where the device was found is returned using the aDeviceInfo parameter.
member.param: String representing the device to find. Can be a MAC, IP or device name.
member.returns: A Handle to the PvDeviceInfo object or null if the device is not found.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvSystem.Find
member.summary: Find all interfaces and GigE Vision, USB3 Vision and Pleora Protocol devices reachable from this system (the PC).

remarks.para: The and ::Find methods search for all GigE Vision, USB3 Vision and Pleora Protocol devices reachable from this system. The version searches using all interfaces on the system; the version, only one interface. The former works as if making multiple, simultaneous calls to the later, albeit concurrently.
The methods are blocking and won't return for the duration set using .

remarks.para: PvSystem finds all interfaces (network adapters) and returns objects. finds all devices on a specific interface and returns objects. provides the information required to connect to a GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvSerialBridge.HardCodedBaudRate
member.summary: Returns the device hard-coded baud rate (user-defined).

remarks.para: Zero (0) is returned if the bridge is not started or in serial COM port mode.
Sets the device hard-coded baud rate (user-defined)

If the device GenICam interface does not have the features to control the configuration of the serial port used by the bridge, the developer must know and provide the baud rate to which the serial port is hard-coded.

This hard-coded baud rate is only used to control which unique baud rate is made available to the application or CLProtocol DLL using the Camera Link DLL. This unique baud rate must match the hard-coded device serial port baud rate.
This method should be called after starting the Camera Link DLL bridge, but before starting the application using the Camera Link DLL or before creating the CLProtocol node map.

With a serial COM port, the baud rate of the COM port is specified through the PvSerialPortConfiguration parameter passed to the Start method and simply isn't used to set the device serial port baud rate. The hard coded baud rate does not need to be defined.

If the device GenICam interface does not have the features to control the configuration of the serial port and this method is not called to specify the hard-coded baud rate of the serial port, 9600 baud is used/assumed.

Valid baud rates are the intersection between the device serial port baud rates and what is described in the Camera Link specification:
9600 baud.
19200 baud.
38400 baud.
57600 baud.
115200 baud.

member.exception:
Failure to set the device hard-coded baud rate can produce a PvException of the following result codes:
if the bridge is not started.
if the baud rate is not supported.
if the bridge is not in Camera Link DLL mode.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvSerialBridge.BaudRate
member.summary: Returns the active baud rate of the device serial port used by the bridge.

remarks.para: Zero (0) is returned if the bridge is not active.
If the device serial port baud rate cannot be retrieved, the serial COM port baud rate is returned if the bridge is used on a serial COM port.
If the bridge is used on a Camera Link DLL, the hard-coded baud rate specified using the HardCodedBaudRate property is returned.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvSerialBridge
member.summary: Bridges a COM port of Camera Link DLL to a device serial port.

remarks.para: Notes: This class is only available on Windows.
The serial bridge takes all the data coming from either a COM port or eBUS SDK Camera Link DLL (clserpte.dll) and sends to a device serial port.
It also takes all the data coming from a device serial port and sends it to either a COM port or eBUS SDK Camera Link DLL.
Depending on the Start method that is used, the bridge is either started as a COM port bridge or Camera Link DLL bridge.
Statistics can be retrieved about a bridge: count of transmitted and received bytes.

The COM port can be used with a stand-alone application, usually a camera configuration application relying on a COM port (ie: COM1, COM2, etc.) to interact with the camera. The port selected by the application must be connected with a NULL modem to the port used by the bridge. It can be two real COM ports connected together or two virtual ports with a COM port emulation software/driver.

The Camera Link DLL can be used with a stand-alone application, usually a camera configuration application, relying on the API described in the Camera Link standard used to interface a serial port. Instead of being the serial port of a frame grabber here it is the serial port of a GigE Vision device.
The Camera Link DLL can also be used with a PvGenParameterArrayCL - a GenICam CLProtocol interface.

member.summary: Static method used to query if a PvGenParameterArray supports file access.

remarks.para: A PvGenParameterArray must support the following features in order to allow access to device files through GenICam:

item.description: PvGenEnum.FileSelector
PvGenEnum.FileOperationSelector (must contain "Open", "Close", "Read", "Write" operations)
PvGenEnum.FileOpenMode (must contain "Read", "Write")
PvGenInteger.FileAccessOffset
PvGenInteger.FileAccessLength
PvGenRegister.FileAccessBuffer
PvGenEnum.FileOperationStatus (must contain "Success" enum entry)
PvGenCommand.FileOperationExecute
PvGenInteger.FileOperationResult

member.param: Handle to
member.returns: True if supported, false if not.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvGenFile.Status
member.summary: Gets the status of the last operation on a PvGenFile.

remarks.para: Last status of a read or write operation as provided by the device. The only enum entry guaranteed to be provided by all devices is "Success" and everything else is quality of implementation.
As an example, the reference GenApi implementation for files assumes end-of-file (EOF) if anything else other than "Success" is reported after a read or a write.
Open, Close, Read and Write operations can get the status through GetStatus. The GetStatus shows the success or failure (or EOF) of the operation on the device.

member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
(Use to get more information).
if the file is not opened.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvFPSStabilizer.IsTimeToDisplay(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Checks whether displaying a frame now would bring us close to the desired display frame rate or not.
member.remarks: If the new frame will bring you closer to your desired frame rate, the method returns true and you send the frame to be displayed to a PvDisplayControl or your own display class. If it returns false, this new frame would bring you above the desired display rate. The frame can still be processed, etc. but displaying it would bring you above the desired frame rate. The expected course of action would then be to simply not display the frame and wait for a new incoming frame - instead of holding to the current one and trying to display it later.
member.param: The target (desired) display frame rate.
member.returns: True if the frame should be displayed, false if not.

member.summary: Finalizer.

member.summary: Destructor.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvFPSStabilizer.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvFPSStabilizer
member.summary: Display frame rate manager. Used to stabilize the frames-per-seconds displayed.
member.remarks: This class is pretty simple to use. Just instantiate an object and call the IsTimeToDisplay every time you have a new frame to display, specifying the desired frame rate. This class is not tied to the display. It simply keeps track of the times associated with displayed frames (IsTimeToDisplay returning true) in a circular buffer and uses this history to decide if it is time to display a new frame.

member.remark: See warnings about accessing the register map directly in . aValue is provided in the platform's expected Endianess. GigE Vision single register operations are always performed as Big Endian and on Intel platforms are corrected to/from Little Endian.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceGEV.NegotiatePacketSize(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Automatically finds and sets the optimal packet size.

remark.para: This method tests the network connection for the largest possible packet size that the network can support between the GigE Vision transmitter and the controlling PC.

Calling this method resets the streaming destination for aChannel. You should always call this method AFTER connecting, BEFORE setting the GigE Vision streaming destination using SetStreamDestination.

The highest possible packet size from { 9000, 8000, 4000, 2000, 1500, 1000, 600 } is used. These values are used as raw seeds and are adjusted by removing 24 bytes for the Ethernet layer and then rounded down to meet the increment requirement imposed by the GevSCPSPacketSize parameter.

member.param: The streaming channel. Use 0 for most GigE Vision devices only supporting a single streaming channel.
The packet size to use, in bytes, should the negotiation fail. Use 1476 for a safe packet size; 0 to continue using the GigE Vision device's original setting in case of failure.
member.exception: Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceGEV.NegotiatePacketSize(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Automatically finds and sets the optimal packet size.

remark.para: This method tests the network connection for the largest possible packet size that the network can support between the GigE Vision transmitter and the controlling PC.

Calling this method resets the streaming destination for aChannel. You should always call this method AFTER connecting, BEFORE setting the GigE Vision streaming destination using SetStreamDestination.

The highest possible packet size from { 9000, 8000, 4000, 2000, 1500, 1000, 600 } is used. These values are used as raw seeds and are adjusted by removing 24 bytes for the Ethernet layer and then rounded down to meet the increment requirement imposed by the GevSCPSPacketSize parameter.

member.param: The streaming channel. Use 0 for most GigE Vision devices only supporting a single streaming channel.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceGEV.Connect(System.String,PvDotNet.PvAccessType)
member.summary: Connect to a GigE Vision device.
member.remark:
If you know the GigE Vision device's IP address, MAC address or DeviceUserID, you can use this method to connect to it. 1. If aInfo contains an IP address, the connection attempt is direct. 2. If aInfo contains a MAC address or DeviceUserID:
An internal is used to find all reachable GigE Vision devices.
Found devices are browsed, looking for a match on either MAC address or DeviceUserID.
If the device is found, connection is attempted.
member.param: Information that uniquely identifies the GigE Vision device. You may use one of the following: - GigE Vision device's MAC address. Use the form 00:11:22:33:44:5F. - GigE Vision device's IP Address. Use the form 192.168.1.114. - GigE Vision device's DeviceUserID.
The access control privilege to set at the time of connection.
member.exception: Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvTruesenseConverter
member.summary: Converts images from TRUESENSE(TM) to RGB.

remarks.para: This class can be used to convert Sparse Color Filter TRUESENSE(TM) images (SCF1) into RGB8 or RGBa8. The image quality is expected to be much better than SCF1 conversion performed using PvBufferConverter.
The intense image processing algorithms used to obtain this high quality yields much higher processing times. Various gain and filtering parameters can be used to tweak the image conversion.

SCF1 12-unpacked is recommended as input pixel type for slightly better processing times. Other SCF1 pixel types are also supported but must internally be converted to 12-unpacked before being converted to RGB.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenStateStack
member.summary: Performs changes to a GenICam node map, tracks them and restores the previous state on destruction.

remarks.para: This class can be used to make temporary changes to a GenICam node map. Every parameter changed through this class is tracked and its original value is saved. When the object is destroyed, the original value of all parameters is restored in the reverse order.

This class is very useful when dealing with selectors. If you want to change a selected value without affecting the current selector state of the node map, create an object of this type, change the selector(s) using the Set methods, perform your changes and let the object go out of scope: the selectors will go back to their original values.

Assume A is originally 1, B is 2, C is 3. If you use this class to change A 4, B to 5 and C to 6 (in that order) when the object goes out of scope C will be set back to 3, B to 2 and A to 1 (in that order as well).
If a value cannot be set (an error occurs) the previous value is not pushed on the stack of parameters that will be restored when the destructor is called.

If the parameter is already set to the requested value, its value IS NOT changed, and IS NOT pushed on the stack to be eventually restored. This is done to minimize traffic to the device and to avoid having too many invalidators to be fired when a selector is already set to the right value.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceI2CBus.IndirectBurstWrite(System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Send a command to the camera (for cameras with memory offsets).
member.remarks:
Before using this method, see BurstWrite. The IndirectBurstWrite method is very similar to the BurstWrite method, with the following exceptions:
This method includes a memory offset, aOffset, that lets you write to a series of memory addresses in the camera.
member.param: The camera's I2C slave address (7-bits).
The address offset of the slave in question.
Data being written on the I2C bus.
The I2C bus speed. Default value is True for I2C's Fast mode (400 Kbits/s); false for Standard mode (100 Kbits/s).
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
if the port is not initialized.
if the port is not opened or the associated PvDevice is no longer connected.
if not all bytes could be written to the serial port.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceI2CBus.BurstWrite(System.Byte,System.Byte[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Send a command to the camera.
member.remarks:
Before using BurstWrite, confirm it meets your camera's requirements:
If your I2C-capable camera uses a single memory location (for the entire streamed message, use BurstWrite and BurstRead.
If it uses sequential memory (storing messages in a series of bytes in memory), use IndirectBurstWrite and IndirectBurstRead.
The BurstWrite method sends a message, aBuffer, to the I2C-capable camera defined by aSlaveAddress.
If the camera doesn't acknowledge a byte during the burst write, BurstWrite terminates early, but returns PV_RESULT_OK.
member.param: The camera's I2C slave address (7-bits).
Data being written on the I2C bus.
The I2C bus speed. Default value is True for I2C's Fast mode (400 Kbits/s); false for Standard mode (100 Kbits/s).
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing the following result code:
if the port is not initialized.
if the port is not opened or the associated PvDevice is no longer connected.
if not all bytes could be written to the serial port.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDeviceI2CBus.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvDeviceI2CBus
member.summary: I2C serial controller.

remarks.para: The PvDeviceI2CBus lets you send commands to your camera and receive the camera's replies.

I2C uses the concept of a master and slave, where the master controls the clock and initiates reads and writes. For PvDeviceI2CBus, the video interface is the I2C master. The I2C slave is typically a camera, but could be any I2C-capable device connected to the video interface.

The PvDeviceI2CBus methods manage the entire video interface and camera communication required to send a message to the camera. For example, the BurstWrite method involves the following transaction:
PC calls BurstWrite.
PC passes entire message to the video interface via Ethernet.
BurstWrite blocks.
video interface to camera: [Start condition] aSlaveAddress [Write - SDA low].
Camera to video interface: Acknowledge.
video interface to camera: [First 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to video interface: Acknowledge.
video interface to camera: [Next 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to video interface: Acknowledge.
...
video interface to camera: [Last 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to video interface: Acknowledge.
video interface to camera: [Stop condition].
video interface reports the successful transmission of the message to the PC (via Ethernet).
BurstWrite method unblocks (returns).
For the complete hardware-level transactions for all PvDeviceI2CBus methods, see your hardware guide.

para.b: To send I2C-protocol serial commands to your camera:

item.description: Create an I2C serial controller of the PvDeviceI2CBus class.
Send a command to the camera. Use BurstWrite.
Test to ensure the message send succeeded. Check the PvResult returned by BurstWrite.
Retrieve the camera's reply. Use BurstRead.
Test to ensure the message retrieval succeeded. Check the PvResult returned by BurstRead.
Test the content of the message from the camera. Use aBuffer and aBufferSize parameters and your own code.

remarks.para: For a simple example illustrating how to use PvDeviceI2CBus, refer to the sample entitled PvI2CSample.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferTextOverlay
member.summary: Provides a text overlay for the buffer about to be displayed.

remarks.para: The display thread only generate the overlay update events. What to do with the overlay is left to the code handling this event.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferLog
member.summary: When buffer logging is enabled, log entries are reported using this event.

remarks.para: The display thread only generate log events. How logging is performed is the responsibility of the application using the display thread.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferDone
member.summary: The display thread has finished handling a buffer.

remarks.para: See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferDisplay
member.summary: A buffer needs to be displayed.

remarks.para: If the acquisition frame rate is higher than the target FPS some buffers may end up not being displayed.
Additional processing may be performed before displaying the image. This step is optional and left to the application. The display thread does not perform image processing.

If interlacing is enabled and an interlaced stream is handled by the display thread, the final buffer being displayed is a buffer that is not directly retrieved from the pipeline (and reported through OnBufferRetrieved). It is a buffer owned by the display thread used for image reconstruction from received field buffers.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferRetrieved
member.summary: A buffer was retrieved from the PvPipeline.

remarks.para: If interlacing is enabled and an interlaced stream is handled by the display thread, the final buffer being displayed is a buffer that is not directly retrieved from the pipeline (and reported through OnBufferRetrieved). It is a buffer owned by the display thread used for image reconstruction from received field buffers.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.VSyncEnabled
member.summary: Vertical synchronization flag.

remarks.para: The display thread does not use this flag, it only keeps it value so it can be read by specialized classes to request a vertical synchronization when a buffer is displayed.
This flag will only have an effect if it is used when the specialized class. Not all display implementations support vertical synchronization.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.TargetFPS
member.summary: Target displayed frames per second.
member.remarks: If the acquisition frame rate is higher than TargetFPS frames are dropped and not displayed. OnBufferDisplay is only invoked on frames that need to be displayed in order to meet TargetFPS.

member.summary: Returns the effective displayed frames per second.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.KeepPartialImagesEnabled
member.summary: If true, attempts to display images with missing packets or lines.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.ReleaseLatestBuffer
member.summary: If true, attempts to display images with missing packets or lines.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.RetrieveLatestBuffer
member.summary: Returns the latest buffer and blocks the pipeline while the buffer is accessed. MUST call ReleaseLatestBuffer when done.

remarks.para: This method should not be on each and every buffers. Use the callbacks instead. A PvBuffer managed wrapper is created on each call to RetrieveLatestBuffer and the display thread is blocked until ReleaseLatestBuffer.
A valid example of RetrieveLatestBuffer would be getting the last acquired image in order to perform on white balance on a RGB filter that is handled outside of the display thread.

member.returns: The latest buffer.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.Resend(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resends the action command using the same request ID.

remarks.para: An application that receives an action command with the same request ID will acknowledge it but not execute the action if it was previously received.

Resends are not managed automatically, as different applications may have different requirements for resending action commands. Resends need to be explicitly managed and performed when acknowledgements are missing.

member.param: Maximum time to wait for answers in ms.
If different than zero, Send can return as soon as aDeviceCount acknowledgements have been received without having to wait for aTimeout.
Asks the devices for acknowledgements of the action command.

item.description: if the command was never sent before Resend was called.
if the content of the command has changed since the last Send operation. A resend cannot be performed if the command is not exactly the same.
if the provided timeout expired before the reception of all the acknowledgements were received.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.Send(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Broadcasts the action command on all enabled network interfaces.

remarks.para: If more than one network interface is enabled, broadcasts are sent on each network interface (one after the other, in the order they were added to the action command object) and the SDK waits (up to the amount of time specified by aTimeout) to receive acknowledgements from each of these interfaces.
When Send is used, the request ID of the action command is automatically incremented. Use Resend to send the same action command without incrementing the request ID.

The action command itself does not know how many devices are reached with this broadcast: all devices receiving the action command that are configured to react to it (combination of device key, group key and group mask) are expected to perform the task associated with the action.

member.param: Maximum time to wait for answers in ms.
If different than zero, Send can return as soon as aDeviceCount acknowledgements have been received without having to wait for aTimeout.
Asks the devices for acknowledgements of the action command.

item.description: if the provided timeout expired before the reception of all the acknowledgements were received.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.ScheduledTime
member.summary: Action command scheduled time.

remarks.para: Action commands can either be performed on reception (no scheduled time enabled or provided) or they can be scheduled in the future. If a timestamp (device time domain) is provided, the device queues the action command and performs the associated task as close to the scheduled action command timestamp as possible. If the device receives a timestamp set in the past relative to its time domain, it is expected to execute the command on reception. The queue the device uses to hold future actions may be limited. If a new command is received and the device is not able to add it to a full queue, the sender is notified (if an acknowledgement of the action command was requested). The scheduled time is only used when the SetScheduledTimeEnable is True.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.ScheduledTimeEnable
member.summary: Action command object scheduled time.

remarks.para: Action commands can either be performed on reception (no scheduled time enabled and provided) or they can be scheduled in the future. This function allows the user to control when the scheduled action command is enabled.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.GroupMask
member.summary: Action command group mask.

remarks.para: A group mask can be configured for an action command. This mask is applied by the device against the group mask of the action command. If the resulting value is non-zero, the action is executed by the device. The group mask for device actions is typically configured using the GenICam interface of the device. The group mask is defined at the action level: different actions on a device can have different group masks.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.GroupKey
member.summary: Action command group key.

remarks.para: The group key defines a group of devices on which actions have to be executed. If a device supports action 1 with a group key of 0x24 and action 2 with a group key of 0x42, when an action command with group key 0x24 is sent, only action 1 is executed. The group key for device actions is typically configured using the GenICam interface of a device. The group key is defined at the action level: different actions on a device can have a different group keys.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.DeviceKey
member.summary: Action command device key.

remarks.para: The device key is a 32-bit value used to check the validity of action commands. Devices only process action commands if the action commands device key matches the devices device key think of it as a secret password provided by action commands that must match the password configured on the device. The device key on the device is typically configured using the GenICam interface of the device. The device key is defined at the device level.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand
member.summary: Utility class to send action commands.

remarks.para: PvActionCommand adds the ability to fire action commands, as defined in the GigE Vision standard.

To use a PvActionCommand, you instantiate an object from the class, configure the command to send, send the command and then optionally retrieve statistics about the outcome of the command. It is possible to use the same action command object to send more than one command: to send the same command, call Send as many times as required. To send different commands, change the configuration of the command between Send calls.

The eBUS SDK does not configure action commands on the device directly. Instead, the SDK assumes that the user is manually configuring action commands with the GenICam browser in the eBUS Player sample application, or is configuring action commands programmatically (assuming that the devices GenICam interface allows the user to configure the device directly).

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamInfo.GetWarnings(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns warnings string.
member.param: Boolean flag to indicate if the pipeline buffers have been reallocated.
member.returns:
Warnings string. which can include:
buffers reallocated. Indicates that the buffers are not large enough to store the incoming image. If your application uses PvPipeline for streaming, this warning also indicates that the buffers have been automatically resized to ensure they are large enough to fit subsequent images. If your application uses PvPipeline, you can safely ignore this message.
resends. The GigE Vision device has received requests from the eBUS Universal Pro for Ethernet driver to resend packets. This indicates that at least one packet was lost.
missing block IDs. Indicates that there are missing blocks (images) in the stream.
pipeline dropped images. Indicates that a received block (image) was dropped in the pipeline and is no longer available for retrieval. This can happen when buffers are not retrieved fast enough by your application.
device dropped images. Indicates that the device has dropped blocks (images) and cannot transmit all of the images received from the sensor.
partial lines missing, full lines missing. Indicates that frames are ending early (FVAL goes invalid before the full number of lines) or lines are ending early (LVAL goes invalid before the full number of pixels). For detailed information about why these warnings are reported, and for information about resolving them, see the Stream Control Application Note, available at http://www.pleora.com/support-center.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.OnBufferTooSmall
member.summary: PvPipeline event sink OnBufferTooSmall event.

remarks.para: Invoked when the pipeline retrieve a buffer from the stream object which failed with an operation result set to BUFFER_TOO_SMALL.
The user can set the delegate aReallocAll parameter to true in order to force a complete re-allocation of the buffers performed synchronously after the notification is invoked.

If OnBufferTooSmall is not handled or the delegate aReallocAll parameter is set to false, the buffer is re-allocated before being queued in the stream object but the other buffers are not affected until they too will fail on BUFFER_TOO_SMALL.
The delegate aResetStats parameter is only considered if the delegate aReallocAll is set to true. The statistics do not need to be reset if the buffers are not re-allocated.
This callback is invoked from the pipeline thread.
See delegate documentation for more information.

remarks.para: Invoked after the pipeline has been reset. This callback is invoked from the same thread that called PvPipeline.Reset.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.BufferHandlingThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the pipeline thread.
member.remarks:
This thread is pretty much the pipeline itself: it queues buffers in PvStream and retrieves them when they are ready, making them available in an output queue.
If you change the thread priorities, it may alternate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.HandleBufferTooSmall
member.summary: Configures whether the pipeline handles BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation result or not.

remarks.para: If the pipeline is configured to handle BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results the buffers are automatically re-allocated and re-queued for acquisition when this condition occurs.

If the pipeline is not configured to handled BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results the buffers are queued in the pipeline output queue just as any other buffer and what to do with the buffer is deferred to the application using PvPipeline.

If the pipeline handles BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results, the OnBufferTooSmall delegate is invoked in order to order to query how to handle the condition. If not implemented the default behaviour is applied. See documentation about the OnBufferTooSmall delegate for more information.
The OnBufferTooSmall delegate is not invoked when the pipeline is not configured to handle BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.BufferCount
member.summary: Returns and set buffer count.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.BufferSize
member.summary: Returns and set buffer size.

remarks.para: Each time a buffer is queued into the data receiver, it is re-allocated as necessary according to the following behavior: if the buffer size is less than the require buffer size (BUFFER_TOO_SMALL) it is re-allocated. If the buffer size is more than four times the required buffer size, it is re-allocated in order to save memory.

Originally the buffer size can be specified using SetBufferSize. The pipeline automatically adjusts the buffer size based on incoming buffers. As buffers are returned to the pipeline and being queued by the data receiver they may be re-allocated as described above.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvPipeline
member.summary: Helper class for receiving data from a GigE Vision or USB3 Vision transmitter.

item.description: PvPipeline manages the PvBuffer and acquisition thread.
PvPipeline partners with a PvStream or PvStreamRaw object to allocate and push buffers into the data receiver as needed.
Only applied to simple acquisition scenarios.
Only responsible of receiving images.
Buffers are silently dropped when the out-queue of the PvPipeline is full.
Does not interact with the device.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.OnBufferTooSmall
member.summary: PvPipeline buffer too small event delegate.
member.param: Reference to the PvPipeline object that invoked the delegate.

Output parameter: if set to true by the delegate handler, all buffers of the pipeline will be re-allocated immediately. If set to false, buffers are re-allocated one-by-one as they fail with BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation result.
Output parameter: if true, the statistics are reset following buffers re-allocation.

member.summary: Reads from the serial port.

members.member:
Gets the progress of an ongoing write operation.
This method can be called from a different thread than the blocking Write call in order track or report the progress of the operation.
After a successful write operation, this method returns aWritten equals to aTotal until the begining of the next write operation.
How many bytes have been written up to now. Total number of bytes to write. Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
if no write operation has been performed yet. \return Includes: - #PvResult::Code::OK - #PvResult::Code::STATE_ERROR if no write operation has been performed yet.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvDeviceSerialPort
member.summary: Provides access the a serial port on a Pleora GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device.
member.remarks:
PvDeviceSerialPort uses a proprietary serial communication protocol on top of the GigE Vision or USB3 Vision protocols. It does not support non-Pleora devices.
Use of the PvDeviceSerialPort class to directly access the camera head will interfere with the synchronization between the device and the camera head. Avoid accessing device features linked to the camera head while using the PvDeviceSerialPort class to interact with the camera head.
How to use this class
To use a serial port:
Connect to a device using any of the Connect method of PvDevice class.
Open a serial port to the device using Open method of PvDeviceSerialPort class.
Write to the serial port using Write method of PvSerialPort class.
Read from the serial port using Read method of PvSerialPort class.
Finally close the serial port using Close method of PvDeviceSerialPort class. To check if an device supports a specific serial port:
Connect to a device using any of the Connect method of PvDevice class.
Use the IsSupported static method of PvDeviceSerialPort class.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvCameraBridge.StartAcquisition
member.summary: Starts the acquisition on the camera.

remarks.para: Uses the GenApi interface to set TLParamsLocked and execute the AcquisitionStart command if these parameters exist. If they do not exist the function still succeeds.

Some cameras only stream if AcquisitionStart/AcquisitionStop and TLParamsLocked are managed properly. In a generic camera bridge application it is recommended to always call StartAcquisition and StopAcquisition on the camera bridge after starting and before stopping acquisition on the device (grabber) itself.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvConfigurationWriter
member.summary: Save the state of the system.
member.remarks:
You can save:
The GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device's state (all parameters that can be streamed).
The SDK's state (stream information and information needed to connect to a GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device).
Your own custom strings and property lists.
To save your state information:
1. Create a configuration writer. Use .
2. Store state information in the configuration writer.
For device controllers (PvDevice objects), use Store(PvDevice, String).
For stream channel receivers (PvStream objects), use Store(PvStream, String).
3. Optionally, store your own state information. Use Store(String, String).
4. Optionally, repeat the two previous steps.
5. Save the stored information to disk. Use .

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvConfigurationReader
member.summary: Restore the state of the system.
member.remarks:
To load your device controller (PvDevice object) or stream controller (PvStream object) state from disk:
1. Create a configuration reader.
2. Load the file from disk. Use . 3. Returns the number of configurations. Use the following properties:
4. Optionally, test for the name of a configuration. Use the following methods:
5. Apply a configuration to an object. Use the following methods:
Note:
If the GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device controller (PvDeviceGEV or PvDeviceU3V object) isn't connected to the device, it attempts to connect (as if calling PvDevice.Connect). If already connected, the settings are applied without changing the IP address and related information. The same applies to a PvStreamGEV or PvStreamU3V that is already opened.

Gets the Speed of the USB host controller.
Even if a USB host controller supports super speed it does not guarantee a device will be connected as super speed. Bad cables or hubs not supporting super speed could force the controller and device to end up being connected at a slower speed.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStreamGEV.UserModeDataReceiverThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the thread used to run the data receiver user mode
member.remarks: Only applicable if using a user-mode data receiver. The thread priority of a driver-based data receiver cannot be controlled. This thread receives and processes all packets received from the device. If you change the thread priorities, it may alternate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamGEV.Open(System.String,System.String,System.UInt16,System.UInt16,System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Begin receiving blocks (images or raw data) multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter.

remarks.para: Note that this overload of Open is for receiving blocks that are multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter to a given multicast group. To receive unicasted data, refer to the other group of overloads of the Open method.
Multicasting is the delivery of data to a group of receivers simultaneously in a single transmission.

The following example illustrates how to multicast data from one transmitter to a given set of receivers:
Connect receivers and transmitter to an IGMP compliant switch.
The GigE Vision transmitter begins transmitting to a multicast group (i.e. 239.192.1.1:1042).
The GigE Vision transmitter has a control channel listening for device discovery requests and packet resend requests on a given IP address (i.e. 169.254.1.1).
Receiver applications discover the device and subscribe to the multicast group (call Open( "169.254.1.1", "239.192.1.1", 1042 ))

Why does the GigE Vision device address (aIPAddress) need to be specified? In this example, the data is transmitted using the GVSP protocol to a multicast group (239.192.1.1:1042). The receiving application contacts the device (IP address 169.254.1.1) using the GVCP protocol to ensure that it is reachable. In addition to this, packet resend requests are directed from receiver to GigE Vision device using the GVCP control channel. This is by design as per the GigEVision standard.

Multicasting uses the IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol) and requires an IGMP-compliant switch. The switch maintains a list of subscribed peers associated with a given multicast group. Multicast group IP addresses take the form 239.192.xx.yy. It is also possible to use multicasting with a non-IGMP compliant switch or network. In that case, the multicast stream is simply broadcasted to every connected entity on the network. It can be OK in controlled environment, but use with caution! To learn more about IGMPv3, see RFC 3376 at www.ietf.org.

For a complete illustration of how to use this method to receive data multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter, refer to the following two samples:
MulticastMaster - Connects to a GigE Vision device as a controler and tells it to begin streaming to a multicast address.
MulticastSlave - Illustrates the use of multicast version of Open by receiving the data the GigE Vision device is transmitting.

member.param: The GigE Vision transmitter's IP address.

The multicast IP address to which the receiver subscribes and the GigE Vision transmitter sends data. (Set the streaming channel destination address (SCDA) on your GigE Vision transmitter accordingly by calling PvDevice::SetStreamDestination.)

The multicast port to which the receiver subscribes and the GigE Vision transmitter sends data. (Set the streaming channel port (SCP) on your GigE Vision transmitter accordingly by calling PvDevice::SetStreamDestination.)
The GigE Vision transmitter's streaming channel (default 0).
Deprecated, ignored.
The maximum number of buffers that can be stored simultaneously in the data receiver.
member.exception: Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.PayloadSize
member.summary: Returns the payload size the device is currently configured to stream with.

remarks.para: This method attempts to read the GenICam PayloadSize parameter of the device. If the operation fails the payload size is computed from width, height and pixel format as a fall back. If even this fails, a value that is still valid to allocate buffers is finally returned.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.StreamDisable(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Disables streaming on the device.

remark.para: For GigE Vision devices, this takes care of resetting the TLParamsLocked so that changes to streaming related parameters are possible again.
For USB3 Vision devices, this takes care of the TLParamsLocked and sets the streaming enable bit on the device.
StreamDisable should be called after the AcquisitionStop GenICam command has been executed and all images have been received.

member.param: The channel on which to disable streaming.

item.description: OK
NOT_CONNECTED
GENERIC_ERROR
INVALID_PARAMETER

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.StreamDisable

remark.param: See the method to disable streaming on the device with specified channel.
remark.para: For GigE Vision devices, this takes care of resetting the TLParamsLocked so that changes to streaming related parameters are possible again.
For USB3 Vision devices, this takes care of the TLParamsLocked and sets the streaming enable bit on the device.
StreamDisable should be called after the AcquisitionStop GenICam command has been executed and all images have been received.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.StreamEnable(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Enables streaming on the device.

remark.param: Method to enable streaming on the device with specified channel.
remark.para: For GigE Vision devices, this takes care of resetting the TLParamsLocked so that changes to streaming related parameters are possible again.
For USB3 Vision devices, this takes care of the TLParamsLocked and sets the streaming enable bit on the device.
StreamDisable should be called after the AcquisitionStop GenICam command has been executed and all images have been received.

member.param: The channel on which to enable streaming.

item.description: OK
NOT_CONNECTED
GENERIC_ERROR
INVALID_PARAMETER

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.StreamEnable
member.summary: Enables streaming on the device.

remark.param: See the method to enable streaming on the device with specified channel.
remark.para: For GigE Vision devices, this takes care of setting the TLParamsLocked so that changes to streaming related parameters are prevent in the GenICam interface of the device.
For USB3 Vision devices, this takes care of the TLParamsLocked, configures the driver for streaming and sets the streaming enable bit on the device.
After calling StreamEnable, the user must still execute the AcquisitionStart GenICam command of the device to instruct the device to begin acquisition.

item.description: OK
NOT_CONNECTED
GENERIC_ERROR
INVALID_PARAMETER

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkWriteSafe
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port write, safe version.

remarks.para: Used to report write activity on the GenApi iPort implementation of the GVCP command link of the PvDevice.
The callback is invoked AFTER the write operation. The content of aBuffer represents the data that was written to the device.
This callback is only invoked on a successful read operation.

If the delegate aLength parameter is 4 bytes, that data is represented as a 4 byte value formatted as big-endian. If data is more that 4 bytes, it is presented as a stream of bytes requiring proper interpretation.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkWrite
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port write, unsafe version.
member.remarks: See safe version of this method for more information. When possible, it is recommended to use the safe version of this event.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkReadSafe
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port read, safe version.

remarks.para: Used to report read activity on the GenApi iPort implementation of the GVCP command link of the PvDevice.
The callback is invoked AFTER the read operation so the content of aBuffer contains the data that was read from the device.
This callback is only invoked on a successful read operation.

If the delegate aLength parameter is 4 bytes, that data is represented as a 4 byte value formatted as big-endian. If data is more that 4 bytes, it is presented as a stream of bytes requiring proper interpretation.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkRead
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port read, unsafe version.
member.remarks: See safe version of this method for more information. When possible, it is recommended to use the safe version of this event.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnEventGenICam
member.summary: Messaging channel GenICam event notification.

remarks.para: This OnEvent handler lets users access the event as mapped through the GenApi interface of the device.

Unlike the other OnEvent that provides a pointer to the raw event data, the data is provided as a list of GenICam parameters that have been invalidated when the event has been attached to the GenApi node map of the device.

If events with no data or events with data not mapped in the GenICam interface of the device are received, this callback is still invoked by the parameter list containing is not provided, it is simply set to NULL.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnEventSafe
member.summary: Messaging channel raw event notification - safe version.

remarks.para: If the delegate aData parameter is not NULL, it is as received on the wire in the device's endianess. All other parameters are corrected for the host's endianess.
The OnEvent handler lets users access the raw event before it is forwarded to the GenICam layer.
It is highly recommended to always use the OnEventGenICam when possible. Use of raw events assume a good knowledge of the device implementation like event ID and data mapping.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnEvent
member.summary: Messaging channel raw event notification - unsafe version.
member.remarks: See safe version of this method for more information. When possible, it is recommended to use the safe version of this event.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnLinkReconnected
member.summary: Callback that is invoked just after PvDevice automatically reconnects with the device.

remarks.para: See delegate documentation for more information.

This callback is invoked when the PvDevice is configured for automatic reconnection and it was able to reconnect the device. However, it is now recommended to not use this mode: disconnect the device on OnLinkDisconnected and simply try reconnecting with Connect yourself.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.InterruptQueueThreadPriority
member.summary: Set/Get the priority of the interrupt queue thread

remarks.para: This thread is simply used to fire/invoke the OnLinkDisconnected and OnLinkReconnected PvDeviceEventSink events.

This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.InterruptLinkThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the interrupt link thread
member.remarks: Interrupt link thread receives messaging channel packets from the device, sends acknowledge back and queues the message in the interrupt queue. Process and callbacks are not done from this thread. This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.HeartbeatThreadPriority
member.summary: Set/Get the priority of the heartbeat thread

remarks.para: The heartbeat thread priority is critical to most applications. This thread must never starve against any other system thread to the risk of losing the device connection.

This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.Connect(System.String)
member.summary: Connect to a GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device.
member.remarks:
1. If you know the GigE Vision device's IP address, MAC address or DeviceUserID, you can use this method to connect to it. 2. If you know the USB3 Vision device's GUID or DeviceUserID, you can use this method to connect it. 3. If aInfo contains an IP address, the connection attempt connecting a GigE Vision device is direct.
An internal is used to find all reachable GigE Vision devices.
Found devices are browsed, looking for a match on the MAC address.
If the device is found, connection is attempted. 4. If aInfo contains a USB3 Vision GUID:
All USB3 Vision devices are enumerated.
Found devices are browsed, looking for a match on the GUID.
If the device is found, connection is attempted. 5. If aInfo contains a device user ID:
All GigE Vision and USB3 Vision are enumerated.
Found devices are browsed, looking for a match on device user ID.
If the device is found, connection is attempted.
member.param:
Information that uniquely identifies the GigE Vision device. You may use one of the following:
GigE Vision device's MAC address. Use the form 00:11:22:33:44:5F.
GigE Vision device's IP Address. Use the form 192.168.1.114
GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device's DeviceUserID.
USB3 Vision GUID.
member.exception: Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:

member.name: T:PvDotNet.OnLinkReconnectedHandler
member.summary: Deprecated, no longer used.

remarks.para: PvDevice no longer attempts automatic reconnection. After receiving an OnLinkDisconnected notification, it is recommend to properly complete disconnection at the application level and then either attempting reconnection until it succeeds or trying find the device in a loop with PvSystem::FindDevice until it succeeds and then finally reconnecting PvDevice, re-opening PvStream, etc.

member.param: Reference to the device object that invoked this callback.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.OnLinkDisconnectedHandler
member.summary: PvDevice disconnected event delegate.

remarks.para: Device recovery (or reconnection) must be performed at the application level. After a OnLinkDisconnect callback, the current session should be cleaned up (disconnecting or deleting your PvDevice controller, closing your PvStream, etc.) and you should start polling with FindDevice from PvSystem to see when the device is available again. When the device is available, reconnect and restore any previously known good application configuration.
For a complete working example of how to initiate recovery and continue streaming in the event of a connection loss, refer to the C++ ConnectionRecovery sample.

member.param: Reference to the device object that invoked this callback.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvAcquisitionStateManager
member.summary: Acquisition state manager, advanced TLParamsLocked manager.

remarks.para: Contains logic to manage the TLParamsLocked GenICam parameter of a PvDevice over various acquisition modes.

A PvDevice is provided to the constructor of this class. A PvStream is also usually provided. The Start and Stop methods are invoked to start and stop the acquisition. If a stream is not provided, the acquisition state has to be reset manually for some acquisition mode as incoming buffers cannot be reported/counted.

It takes control of issuing Start/Stop methods to the AcquisitionStart and AcquisitionStop GenICam commands of a device. It also counts frames (when applicable) to automatically release TLParamsLocked when all the buffers have been accounted for. It is possible to cancel the operation pre-emptively by calling Stop - if the user wants to cancel the operation or the user knows some buffers were lost and will never come.

By default one conversion thread is created for each processing core of the system. We only allow setting priority for the threads of one converter object as a group.
If you change the thread priorities, it may affect the stability of the system. When communicating with your Pleora representative, ensure you tell them that you have changed the thread priority.

The IsConversionSupported method tests if the Convert function has an available conversion algorithm.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvBufferConverterRGBFilter.Reset
member.summary: Reset the RGB filter configuration.

remarks.para: This method resets the RGB filter configuration (#PvBufferConverterRGBFilter) to its default values.
Gains are set to 1; offsets, to 0. After a reset, applying the filter doesn't change the image.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvBufferConverterRGBFilter.WhiteBalance(PvDotNet.PvBuffer)
member.summary: Calculate white-balance gains.

remarks.para: The WhiteBalance method receives an image and calculates appropriate gains to white-balance the image.

Internally, the #WhiteBalance method uses the following procedure:
Calculate the average colors in the image: Bavg, Gavg, Ravg.
Select the maximum of the three averages: Max = max (Bavg, Gavg, Ravg).
Set the new gains, where Bgain = Max / Bavg, Ggain = Max / Gavg and Rgain = Max / Ravg
The WhiteBalance method produces the best results for images that have an even mix of dark and light tones, and an even mix of colors.

member.param: The sample image; the image upon which to base the white-balance settings.
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
INVALID_PARAMETER.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStream.RetrieveBuffer(PvDotNet.PvBuffer@,PvDotNet.PvResult@)
member.summary: Attempt to retrieve a queued buffer.

remarks.para: To use this method, see also QueueBuffer.
The RetrieveBuffer method blocks until one of the following occurs:

item.description: The buffer is filled with a block (image or raw data).
The retrieve buffer operation times out: it exceeds aTimeout.
The acquisition fails (by being aborted, data receiver timeout as defined by ImageTimeout property, etc.)

remarks.para: Once the method returns, you can determine the ultimate success of the image acquisition by testing the aOperationResult parameter. For example, RetrieveBuffer may return PvResult::Code::OK, even if the operation was aborted by a call to AbortQueuedBuffers or Close.
In this case, aOperationResult would be PvResult::Code::ABORTED.

The return value contains the RetrieveBuffer operation results and aOperationResult contains the actual result (or failure) of the data receiver on this buffer. This method can succeed in providing you the oldest buffer but the result of the operation may still be a failure - if acquisition was aborted, incomplete, etc.

member.param: The buffer that holds the image.
A pointer to the result of the acquisition operation on aBuffer, see PvBuffer::GetOperationResult.

item.description: if the buffer has been properly queued.
if the buffer could not be queued. See PvResult::GetDescription for more information.
if the stream is not connected to a transmitter.
if no buffers queued.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStream.RetrieveBuffer(PvDotNet.PvBuffer@,PvDotNet.PvResult@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Attempt to retrieve a queued buffer.

remarks.para: To use this method, see also QueueBuffer.
The RetrieveBuffer method blocks until one of the following occurs:

item.description: The buffer is filled with a block (image or raw data).
The retrieve buffer operation times out: it exceeds aTimeout.
The acquisition fails (by being aborted, data receiver timeout as defined by ImageTimeout property, etc.)

remarks.para: Once the method returns, you can determine the ultimate success of the image acquisition by testing the aOperationResult parameter. For example, RetrieveBuffer may return PvResult::Code::OK, even if the operation was aborted by a call to AbortQueuedBuffers or Close.
In this case, aOperationResult would be PvResult::Code::ABORTED.

The return value contains the RetrieveBuffer operation results and aOperationResult contains the actual result (or failure) of the data receiver on this buffer. This method can succeed in providing you the oldest buffer but the result of the operation may still be a failure - if acquisition was aborted, incomplete, etc.

member.param: The buffer that holds the image.
A pointer to the result of the acquisition operation on aBuffer, see PvBuffer::GetOperationResult.
The maximum time, in ms, to wait for a buffer to be returned by the data receiver.

item.description: if the buffer has been properly queued.

if no buffers queued.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStream.QueueBuffer(PvDotNet.PvBuffer)
member.summary: Queue a buffer to receive a block.

remarks.para: The method queues in a buffer ( object) to a stream ( object) so it can be filled by the data receiver.
For each buffer you remove (using RetrieveBuffer), you should queue another (using ).
The maximum number of buffers that can be queued at a given time can be obtained by calling .
To reduce the risk of missing incoming data, it is recommended that several blocks remain queued and ready to go at any given time.
Generally it is recommended that a larger number of buffers remain queued for higher frame rates.
Larger block sizes with blocks being streamed at a lower frame rate can afford to allocate fewer buffers to optimize memory usage and reduce potential latency.
Once the stream fills the buffer with a block, retrieve the buffer by calling RetrieveBuffer.

member.param: A handle to the buffer to be filled.

item.description: if the buffer has been properly queued.
if the buffer could not be queued. See PvResult::GetDescription for more information

members.member:
Abort all pending block requests. Once you have aborted pending block requests, they still need to be de-queued. Use RetrieveBuffer. The following PvException result code will be produced:
NOT_CONNECTED

member.summary: Attaches a payload containing data chunks to a GenICam node map.

remarks.para: Takes the content of a PvBuffer and attempts to parse the chunks from the end of the buffer. Chunk IDs from the buffer matching chunk IDs in the node map are available through the node map once the buffer is attached.
Using GenICam instead of the PvBuffer raw chunk methods access allows to access the chunks as structured data, as long as the chunks are described in the GenICam XML file of the device.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenParameterArray
member.summary: GenICam feature array.

remarks.para: 1- Get the list of features. Use one of the following:

item.description: PvDevice.Parameters (Parameters used to control the GigE Vision device to which you are connected).

PvDevice.CommunicationParameters (Parameters used to define how PvDevice connects to and communicates with the device - see Device Communication Parameters for either GigE Vision or USB3 Vision devices.
PvStream.Parameters (Parameters used to define how PvStream receives data from a GigE Vision transmitter - see Stream Parameters for either GigE Vision or USB3 Vision device..

remarks.para: 2- Get a feature. Use .
3- Get the feature's type. Use .

4- Optionally:
Get/Set the feature's value. Use the Value attribute for the feature's type (e.g. PvGenInteger.Value, etc).
If the feature is a command, activate it. Use PvGenCommand.Execute.
To control features (using a GUI): see PvGenBrowserWnd

para.h3: Running code when a feature's value changes

remarks.para: In some cases, you may want to know when a feature value or attribute changes without using CPU-intensive polling to regularly check (and re-check) the feature's value.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvGenRegister.Length
member.summary: Returns the length of the register mapped with this feature.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvGenRegister.Get(System.Byte*,System.Int64)
member.summary: Reads from the register.

remarks.para: Partial (less than ) reads are supported at the GenICam level, but the behavior is defined by the device.

member.param: Data read from the register.
Length of the buffer, in bytes.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvGenRegister.Set(System.Byte*,System.Int64)
member.summary: Write to the register.

remarks.para: Partial (less than ) reads are supported at the GenICam level, but the behavior is defined by the device.
GigE Vision enforces a mod-4 (can be divided by 4 bytes) length restriction on all read/write operations.

member.param: Data write to the register.
Length of the buffer, in bytes.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenEnum
member.summary: GenICam feature: Enumeration. A feature that can take one of many defined values.

remarks.para: In group: GenICam features.
PvGenEnum is a list of selectable values. In a UI, PvGenEnum objects are typically represented as dropdown lists.
Each list entry is a object.
Thus, the enumeration list might be represented as:
However, the UI presents only a selection of entry names (Orange, etc.); the list position and entry values are hidden. The entry names are always unique.
Enumerations can't be set to any arbitrary value; they can only be set to a value of an entry on the list.
If a user selected Orange, you could set the new value in the following ways:

item.description: Set the entry value directly with = 5.
Set the entry value by the name with = "Orange".

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.Undefined
member.summary: Not defined; valid representation not provided.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.HexNumber
member.summary: Hex number. Use an edit box with a hexadecimal display.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.PureNumber
member.summary: Pure number. Use an edit box with a decimal display.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.Boolean
member.summary: Boolean. The number might be presented as a check box or enable. Use a similar UI as for features from the PvGenBoolean class.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.Logarithmic
member.summary: Logarithmic. Use a slider. The GenICam standard doesn't specify if the feature's value represents x or y in the formula x = n ^ y.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvGenRepresentation.Linear
member.summary: Linear. Use a slider.

remarks.para: Every feature has a visibility setting that suggests how difficult the feature is to use and when it shouldn't be made available (visible) to the end user.
The current visibility might be a program-specific variable available, for example, in an options or configuration dialog.
When opening the program for the first time, the visibility would typically be set to beginner.
If a program's current visibility were set to Expert, the user would expect to see Beginner and Expert-level features, but not Guru or Invisible-level features.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.BufferPoolThreadPriority
member.summary: Gets or Sets the priority of the thread used to manage the buffer of the buffer pool

remarks.para: Only applicable if using a buffer pool. The thread will manage the buffer exchange with the transmitter.
If you change the thread priorities, it may alternate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.UserModeTransmitterThreadPriority
member.summary: Gets or Sets the priority of the thread in charge of sending the packets on the network.

remarks.para: Only applicable if using a user-mode transmitter. The thread priority of a driver-based transmitter cannot be controlled. Thread that is responsible for breaking buffers in packets and transmitting them.
If you change the thread priorities, it may alternate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.AverageTransmissionRate
member.summary: Gets the average transmission rate (in blocks/second).

remarks.para: Average transmission rate is equivalent to BlocksTransmitted / SamplingTime.
This function is the transmitter counterpart to the property AcquisitionRateAverage of PvStatistics.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.InstantaneousTransmissionRate
member.summary: Gets the instantaneous transmission rate (in blocks/second).

remarks.para: Instantaneous transmission rate is measured using a short time frame.
This function is the transmitter counterpart to the property AcquisitionRate of PvStatistics.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.AveragePayloadThroughput
member.summary: Gets the average payload throughput (in bps).

remarks.para: Average payload transmission rate is equivalent to PayloadBytesTransmitted * 8 / SamplingTime.
Note that this calculation only includes the number of useful data bytes and does not include GVSP, IP and UDP header overhead.
This function is the transmitter counterpart to property BandwidthAverage of PvStatistics.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.InstantaneousPayloadThroughput
member.summary: Gets an instantaneous calculation of the payload throughput (in bps).

remarks.para: Instantaneous payload transmission rate is measured using a short time frame.
Note that this calculation only includes the number of useful data bytes and does not include GVSP, IP and UDP header overhead.
This function is the transmitter counterpart to property Bandwidth of PvStatistics.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.PayloadBytesTransmitted
member.summary: Gets the number of payload bytes transmitted.
member.remarks: Note that this value only includes the number of useful data bytes and does not include GVSP, IP and UDP header overhead.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.MaxPayloadThroughput
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum desired effective throughput in bps.

remarks.para: An occasional delay is placed between the packets being transmitted to attempt to throttle the effective throughput. This helps to spread out network traffic to optimize bandwidth availability for other applications.
A value of 0 (default) indicates that there should be no throttling based on throughput.

The throughput is measured in effective throughput on the content of the transmitted PvBuffer objects. It does not take into account the GigE Vision, UDP, IP and Ethernet protocol overhead of the packetized data.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV.PacketSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum packet size (in bytes) of GVSP payload packets.

remarks.para: When a block is packetized and transmitted, the payload is broken down into packets of a given size. The default value for the maximum packet size is 1440 because that is the size that should work in theory for all network adapters.

For best results, enable jumbo packets in your network adapter properties and increase the maximum packet size to match When sending very small blocks at high frame rates it may sometimes be desirable to set the maximum packet size to a lower number.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterGEV
member.summary: Class for transmitting blocks using the GigE Vision streaming protocol.
member.remarks:
Procedure for transmitting blocks (images or raw data) with the eBUS SDK:
Ensure that the transmitter knows where to send blocks by calling Open.
Initialize the transmitter with a set of free buffers (PvBuffer objects) by calling LoadBufferPool.
Retrieve a free buffer to populate by calling RetrieveFreeBuffer.
Queue a buffer for transmission by calling QueueBuffer.
Once a buffer has been transmitted, it can be retrieved again by calling RetrieveFreeBuffer. The following code snippet illustrates procedure above: The status of a given PvBuffer object can be retrieved by calling OperationResult property of PvBuffer.
An operation result of indicates that the buffer was transmitted successfully.
An operation result of indicates that there was a problem transmitting the buffer (likely due to a lack of connectivity).
An operation result of indicates that the transmission of that buffer was aborted (typically by calling AbortQueuedBuffers).
An operation result of indicates that the buffer has not yet been fully transmitted. To receive transmitted blocks with a PvStream application (such as eBUS Player), the transmitting application must be set up to respond to device discovery requests. Use PvVirtualDeviceGEV to respond to device discovery requests. If using eBUS Player or NetCommand to receive data being transmitted with this class, ensure that the application is set up as Data Receiver Only. For an illustration of how this API is used in practice, refer to the following source code samples in the samples directory where the eBUS SDK resides.
TransmitTestPattern- Transmits a test pattern to a given destination. This is the easiest starting point for learning to use PvTransmitterGEV.
TransmitTiledImages - GUI application that receives video from multiple GEV transmitters, tiles into one video feed and transmits to a given destination.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDeviceInfo.IsLicenseValid
member.summary: Test if the eBUS SDK license is valid for this device.

remarks.para: To connect to third-party GigE Vision devices, the eBUS SDK requires a valid license. If you don't have a license, contact sales.
returns true if the license is valid; otherwise; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDeviceInfo.IsConfigurationValid
member.summary: Test if the device can be reached as currently configured.

remarks.para: This method compares the GigE Vision device and NIC's IP configurations to ensure they are on the same subnet.
For USB3 Vision devices, the configuration is considered valid if the device can be enumerated and the Pleora driver is associated to the device.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDeviceInfo.UniqueID
member.summary: Get a string uniquely identifying this device.

remarks.para: The content of the unique ID is not garanteed to be represent anything or to be constant between revisions of the eBUS SDK. It should only be used to opaquely, uniquely match other device unique IDs from within the same application life cycle.
Do not assume the unique ID will be using a MAC address for network devices or the USB GUID for USB devices.
If you need the MAC address of a GigE Vision device, use PvDeviceInfoGEV.MACAddress.
If you need the USB GUID of a USB3 Vision device, use PvDeviceInfoU3V.GUID.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvTapFilter.GetOutputPixelTypeFor(PvDotNet.PvBuffer)
member.summary: Static method used to query the output pixel type for an input image of a specific pixel type.

remarks.para: This method can be used if the output buffer provided to Execute is attached and not allocated. The filter can re-allocate an allocated buffer if needed (mismatch on width, height or pixel format) but attached external buffers must be properly formatted before calling Execute.

To properly prepare the output buffer, use the same width and height as the input buffer. For the pixel format, use this static method with the input buffer in aBuffer to query the required pixel type of the output buffer.

member.param: Buffer to return the required output pixel type for.
member.returns: The pixel type the filter as currently configured would output.

It is possible to de-interlace a buffer containing both fields using the #Apply method only taking a single input as parameter. With this method, field inversion can be controlled through .

The other method takes two independent objects each containing a field. Even and Odd interlaced fields are required for reconstructions. is ignored when de-interlacing with this method, the user can simply swap the parameters to obtain the same effect.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.GetPayloadSize
member.summary: Returns payload size in bytes, excluding any extra padding.

remarks.para: Gets the size in bytes of the block received by the data receiver including, if present, additional chunk data and headers.
Different than GetAcquiredSize as it does not include optional additional padding when data chunks are present.
If data chunks are not present, this method returns the same value as GetAcquiredSize as extra padding is only an issue when data chunks are present.
This method is required in order to parse the chunk data using GenICam.

member.returns: Payload size in bytes, excluding any extra padding.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.ChunkCount
member.summary: Returns the number of data chunks in the PvBuffer.

remarks.para: If no data chunks are available, 0 is returned.
Counting chunks requires the chunks to be parsed and resolved which has a performance hit.

If you need to access chunks directly, you need to use this method to enumerate the chunks. If you access the chunks through GenICam, just use HasChunks to see if you need to attach the buffer the GenICam parameter array of the device.

If the payload type of the PvBuffer is NOT PvPayloadType.ChunkData, a null reference is returned.
